journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Fault detection for a class of nonhomogeneous Markov jump systems based on delta operator approach

article-meta.aff: 1College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, China
2State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Process Industries, Northeastern University, China

author-notes.corresp: Guang-Hong Yang, College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, No. 11, Lane 3, WenHua Road, HePing District, Shenyang, Liaoning 110819, China. Email: yangguanghong@ise.neu.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: The problem of fault detection for a class of nonhomogeneous Markov jump system is addressed in this article based on a delta operator approach. The system under consideration contains mode-dependent delays, nonlinearities, as well as nonhomogeneous Markov switching. Also, the delta operator provides a theoretically unified formulation of continuous-time and discrete-time systems. In addition to the stochastic H‚àû performance, a new definition of stochastic H‚àí index is introduced from the signal‚Äôs point of view, which gives a measurement of sensitivity from the residuals to the faults. Then, the fault detection scheme is proposed in which the effect of the disturbances on the residuals is minimized; meanwhile, the effect of the faults on the residuals is maximized. Subsequently, novel sufficient conditions are derived to treat this multiobjective optimization problem in a potentially less conservative framework. Especially for the sensitivity performance, a new convex condition, which includes some existing results, is obtained in terms of linear matrix inequalities. Finally, an aircraft application is given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Markov jump systems (MJSs) have great practical potential due to the powerful modeling ability of the Markov process in many fields, such as the aerospace industry, communication systems, biology and medicine, and economics. As a crucial factor, transition probabilities (TPs) in the Markov process determine the behavior and the performance of MJSs.1 Many important issues have been studied extensively for MJSs with certain and complete known TPs such as stability and stabilization,2‚Äì5 control synthesis,6‚Äì8 and filter design.9,10 Presently, some researches on MJSs with uncertain or partially known TPs have been developed.11‚Äì13

It should be pointed out that almost all the aforementioned works assume that the Markov process (or chain) is homogeneous, that is, the TPs are time invariant. Actually, this assumption is usually violated in some applications. A typical example, which is mentioned in Zhang,1 can be found in the vertical take-off landing (VTOL) helicopter system,14 where the airspeed variation involved in the system matrices are ideally modeled as homogeneous Markov process. However, when the external environment (like the wind) is changed, all the probabilities of the jumps among multiple airspeeds will not be fixed. Another example can be found in networked control systems (NCSs) based on the internet.1 It is well known that network-induced delays and packet losses can be modeled by Markov process. However, the delay or the packet loss is distinct at different periods. Thus, the underlying TP matrix may vary throughout the running time of the modeled systems. Therefore, considering time-varying TPs, which is called nonhomogeneous Markov process (or chain), leads to a new research topic. Until now, only a few studies centred on this interesting problem. The H‚àû estimation for a class of MJSs with time-varying TPs in discrete-time domain has been considered in Zhang,1 and the problem of stochastic stabilization has been investigated in Aberkane.15

On the other hand, model-based fault detection (FD) has received more attention, and two commonly used FD methods are H‚àû approaches and H‚àû/H‚àí approaches. In H‚àû approaches, an H‚àû-filtering formulation to solve the FD problem is representative and has received much attention, see the literature for examples.16‚Äì21 Furthermore, in H‚àû/H‚àí approaches, a measurement of the H‚àí index was introduced to weight the sensitivity from the residual to the fault, see, for example, Wang and Yang22 for linear time-invariant systems and for linear parameter-varying systems,23 also Li and Yang24,25 for It√¥ stochastic systems. However, the FD problem for MJSs with consideration of sensitivity has not been developed yet, especially for nonhomogeneous MJSs with mode-dependent delays and nonlinearities, which gives the motivation for our present investigation.

More specifically, the FD problem for a class of nonhomogeneous MJSs is considered in this article based on delta operator approach. The system under consideration involves mode-dependent delays, nonlinearities as well as nonhomogeneous Markov switching. After introducing a new definition of stochastic H‚àí index from the signal‚Äôs point of view, which measures the sensitivity from the residuals to the faults, a FD scheme is constructed in which the effect of the disturbances on the residuals is minimized; meanwhile, the effect of the faults on the residuals is maximized. Subsequently, novel sufficient conditions, which are utilized to formulate the delta operator fault detection filter (DOFDF), are presented in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs).

The main contributions in this article are as follows: (a) In comparison with most of the existing studies of MJSs, the mode-dependent delays, the nonlinearities, and the nonhomogeneous Markov switching are all considered, and therefore, the model in this article is more general to model the practical systems. Also, the delta operator provides a theoretically unified formulation of continuous-time and discrete-time systems. (b) The sensitivity performance is considered in the proposed FD scheme. Furthermore, new sufficient condition, which includes some existing results, to capture such a performance is derived for the considered nonhomogeneous MJSs.

The remainder of the article is organized as follows. The FD problem is formulated in section ‚ÄúProblem formulation and preliminaries.‚Äù The solutions of DOFDF parameters are derived in ‚ÄúMain results‚Äù. ‚ÄúDetection threshold design‚Äù provides residual evaluator and threshold. In ‚ÄúExample‚Äù, an aircraft application is given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Finally, conclusions are given at the end of the article.

sec.title: Delta operator
sec.p: For a continuous-time signal xc(t), the discrete-time sequence by sampling the continuous-time signal is xc(nh), where h is the sampling period and n=0,1,2,‚Ä¶. Assuming that h=0 signifies xc(nh)=xc(t). For h‚â†0, denoting xc(nh)=xd(k) and xc((n+1)h)=xd(k+1), k=0,1,2,‚Ä¶.
The delta operator is defined as follows according to Goodwin et al.26 and Guo and Yang27
where q is the forward shift operator with xd(k) being sampled using forward shift operator approach, that is, q[xd(k)]=q[xc(nh)]=xd(k+1). The relation between q and Œ¥ is
In view of this, Œ¥ is a dynamic operator that provides the same flexibility and implementability as shift operator.26
On the other hand, the delta operator provides the continuity when h‚Üí0. Referring to (1), it can be easily seen that

sec.title: Remark 1
sec.p: It is easily seen, from the above statement, that the delta operator Œ¥ provides a theoretically unified formulation of continuous-time and discrete-time systems. Also, it has the advantage of better numerical properties at high sampling rates.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: On a given probability space (Œ©,F,P), consider the following delta operator MJS

Here and in the sequel, all the matrices are assumed to be with compatible dimensions, and the matrix MŒ∏k=i associated with the ith mode is denoted by Mi.
The process {Œ∏k,k‚â•0} is described by a finite-state Markov chain taking values in a finite set S={1,2,‚Ä¶,N} with generator Œ†(k)=(œÄij(k)) given by
where œÄij(k)>0, for i,j‚ààS, is the transition rate from mode i at time k to mode j at time k+1 while ‚àëj‚ààSœÄij(k)=1.
In this article, the structure of the transition matrix Œ†(k) is assumed to be of the polytopic time-varying form
where œÇl(k) are deterministic scalar functions of k satisfying œÇl(k)‚â•0 and ‚àël=1MœÇl(k)=1, and Œ†l are given TP matrices.

sec.title: Remark 2
sec.p: Equation (4) represents a polytopic time-varying transition matrix, that is, a time-dependent one for Œ∏k. In this case, the Markov chain is said to be nonhomogeneous. If Œ†(k)=Œ† in equation (4), the Markov chain is known as homogeneous.

sec.title: Remark 3
sec.p: The H‚àû estimation problem has been considered in Zhang1 for a class of nonhomogeneous MJSs. The time-varying character of the TP in Zhang1 is piecewise homogeneous with arbitrary variation in a finite set, whose structure is given by
where œÉ(k) is a switching rule that takes its value in the finite set {1,‚Ä¶,œÉ}. It is easily seen that this model is a special case of the proposed polytopic time-varying model.
The nonlinear function g(x(k),x(k‚àídŒ∏k),Œ∏k) consisting of x(k) and x(k‚àídŒ∏k) is bounded in a statistical sense as follows
where Œ±Œ∫(Œ∏k)(Œ∫=1,‚Ä¶,ùìÄ) are known mode-dependent column vectors, and ŒòŒ∫(Œ∏k) and ŒõŒ∫(Œ∏k) are known positive-define mode-dependent matrices.

sec.title: Remark 4
sec.p: The nonlinearities in equation (5) have been described by statistical means in Yaz and Yaz28 and Liu et al.29 Such a description is quite general since it includes many classes of nonlinear systems, for example, the nonlinear systems with random sequences whose powers depend on the sector-bound nonlinear function of the state.29
The following DOFDF will be applied as the residual generator
where x~(k)‚ààRn is the filter state; r(k) is the residual; and, ùíúfi,ùíúfdi, ‚Ñ¨fi, ùíûfi, and ùíüfi are the filter parameter matrices to be designed.
Define Œ∑(k)=[xT(k)x~T(k)]T, the dynamics of the FD system can be described by
where œÜ¬Ø(k)=[œÜT(k)œÜ~T(k)]T, Z=[I0] and
In order to formulate the problem clearly, the following definitions are first given:

sec.title: Definition 11,2 (stochastic stable)
sec.p: The FD system (7) is said to be stochastic stable (SS) with w(k)=0 and f(k)=0 if
holds for all œÜ¬Ø(k) and Œ∏0‚ààùïä.

sec.title: Definition 2 (stochastic H‚àû norm)
sec.p: For the FD system (7), the stochastic H‚àû norm is defined as
where the operator Grw:w(k)‚Üír(k) stands for the mapping from w(k) to r(k) and

sec.title: Definition 3 (stochastic H‚àí index)
sec.p: For the FD system (7), the stochastic H‚àí index is defined as
where the operator Grf:f(k)‚Üír(k) stands for the mapping from f(k) to r(k).

Now, the problem to be addressed in this article is to develop a set of stable DOFDFs (equation (6)) such that, for all mode-dependent nonlinearities and time delays, exogenous disturbances and sensor failures, the FD system (7) is SS, and the effect of the disturbances on the residuals is minimized, that is, ‚à•Grw‚à•‚àûùîº<Œ≥, by satisfying the following specification
Meanwhile, the sensitivity of the faults on the residuals is maximized, that is, ‚à•Grf‚à•‚àíùîº>Œ≤, by satisfying the following condition

sec.title: Remark 5
sec.p: The stochastic H‚àí index was introduced in Li and Yang,25 which measures the sensitivity from the faults f(k) to the residuals r(k). Accordingly, the larger Œ≤ is, the more sensitive it becomes.

sec.title: Remark 6
sec.p: Comparing with the most existing FD techniques for MJSs in which an estimation method has been utilized, the meaningful feature of the proposed FD scheme is to make the generated residuals sensitive to the fault signals. This strategy will make it possible for the generated residuals to have obvious discrepancies between fault-free case and faulty cases. The example in the section ‚ÄúExample‚Äù will demonstrate the effectiveness of our FD approach.

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: In this section, the above formulated FD problem will be investigated. Sufficient conditions to capture the desired performance for the FD system (7) are first given.

sec.title: Performance analysis

By Schur‚Äôs complement, it follows from equation (13) that ùîº{rT(k)r(k)‚àíŒ≥2wT(k)w(k)}+Œ¥V(k)<0. Summing it from k=0 to ‚àû, we have ‚àëk=0‚àû{ùîº(rT(k)r(k)‚àíŒ≥2wT(k)w(k))+Œ¥V(k)}<0, which indicates that J(r,w)<0. That is the inequality (10) holds for all nonzero w(k).
Similar with the above deduction, it is not difficult to derive that Œ¥V(k)<0 with w(k)=0, which implies that the FD system (7) is SS. This proof is completed.‚ÄÉ‚ñ†

sec.title: Remark 7
sec.p: The Lyapunov functional V(Œ∑(k)), as in the above proof can always be given for both continuous-time and discrete-time systems. In additon, when h=1, there exist

The above results imply that the Lyapunov functional for delta operator system can be reduced to the traditional Lyapunov functional for discrete-time and continuous-time systems when the sampling period is 1 or tends to 0.
Next, we will focus on the sensitivity performance analysis for system (7).

sec.title: Proof
sec.p: In order to analyse the H‚àí performance of the system (7) when w(k)=0, the following index is introduced under zero initial conditions œÜ¬Ø(k)=0 and Vs(0)=0
where Vs(k) is the Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii functional with the same structure as V(k) in Theorem 1.
Following the same process as the proof for Theorem 1 and employing Schur‚Äôs complement on (27), we have

Summing (29) from k=0 to ‚àû, we have ‚àëk=0‚àû{ùîº(‚àírT(k)r(k)+Œ≤2fT(k)f(k))+Œ¥Vs(k)}<0, which implies that J(r,f)<0, that is, the inequality (11) holds for all nonzero f(k). This proof is completed.‚ÄÉ‚ñ†

sec.title: Remark 8
sec.p: It is obvious that equations (13) and (27) are not LMIs due to the product terms between the Lyapunov variables ùí´i, ùí´si and the system matrices ùíúi, ùíúfi, ‚Ñ¨i, and Fi, respectively. As a result, the LMI toolbox fails to solve these inequalities. On the other hand, different from the traditional procedure for H‚àû performance analysis wherein Schur‚Äôs complement is utilized to deal with the nonlinear terms ùíûiTùíûi, ùíûiTùíüi, ùíüiTùíüi, and so on. Here, in Theorem 2, the signature of these terms is minus, and Schur‚Äôs complement cannot be used directly. For the sake of overcoming the above-mentioned disadvantages, we introduce some slack variables to solve this problem. Consequently, new sufficient conditions to capture the system performance (10) and (11) will be provided in the next section.

sec.title: DOFDF design
sec.p: In this subsection, sufficient conditions to proceed the DOFDF synthesis will be given in terms of LMIs. Before proceeding further, the following lemma will be recalled to prove our main results.

sec.title: Remark 10
sec.p: It is easily seen from Theorems 3 and 4 that 2√óN√óM2 LMIs should be solved for each performance. A sufficient condition has been given in terms of LMIs to characterize the sensitivity performance by introducing a given matrix L in Li and Yang,25 which can be determined by an iterative algorithm. However, it is too difficult to derive this L because of the arduous calculation task, that is, ‚Ñê(i)√ó2√óN√óM2 (‚Ñê(i) is sum of the iterative times) LMIs must be solved. Also, for high-dimensional dynamical systems or systems, which include many subsystems, it is not easy to determine this L. In this article, a slack variable ‚Ñõi is introduced additionally to derive a convex LMI condition. Such a newly introduced variable ‚Ñõi does not present any structural constraint such as symmetry; however, it can not only reduce the calculation load but also give potentially less conservative results. Furthermore, if ‚Ñãsi is chosen as
the conclusion in Theorem 4 could be equivalent to that in Li and Yang.25
After the above treatment, combining Theorems 3 and 4, a set of optimal solutions for the FD problem can be obtained for given scalar Œ≥ by solving the following optimization problem
Then, the system matrices ùíúfi, ùíúdfi, ‚Ñ¨fi, ùíûfi, and ùíüfi of the DOFDF can be computed via the equality (36).

sec.title: Remark 11
sec.p: It should be claimed that in order to obtain a better sensitivity performance, the optimization problem (45) is solved under an acceptable disturbance attenuation level Œ≥ rather than the best one. On the other hand, to balanced these two performances, the FD problem can also be solved by the following optimization problem

where a and b are weighting factors. Also, the relation between Œ≥ and Œ≤ can be obtained from this presentation, that is, a larger Œ≤ will result in a larger Œ≥, that is, a better fault sensitivity performance can be obtained by sacrificing some level of disturbance attenuation performance.

sec.title: Detection threshold design
sec.p: In this section, the threshold to detect the sensor failures is designed and the detection logic unit is given based on the results in Frank.30
The evaluation function in this article is computed by the following equation since an evaluation of residual signals over the whole time is unrealistic
which gives the average energy of residual signals over a time interval (k1,kœÑ), where k1 denotes the initial evaluation time instant and kœÑ stands for the evaluation time.
Let
be the threshold. Based on this, the occurrence of faults can be detected by comparing Jr(œÑ) and Jth according to the following test

sec.title: Example
sec.p: In this section, an example and simulations are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed FD methods. According to some previous studies of the aircraft dynamic model such as McItuer et al.31 and Adams et al.,32 one knows that the nonlinear aircraft dynamic model is established based on Newton‚Äôs second law of motion. In order to decouple the nonlinear dynamics, the model is decomposed of two models along with longitudinal- and lateral-directional motions, respectively.

The model used in this example is the lateral-directional dynamic model of the NASA High Alpha Research Vehicle (HARV) in Li and Yang25 and Siwakosit et al.33 Wherein the system state and output are as follows
Using delta operator in sampling the continuous-time system in Li and Yang25 with h=1s, the relevant discrete-time system in Œ¥-domain can be obtained as follows
where œÉ(Œ∏k) is an uncertain model parameter.
Also, Œ∏k represent nonhomogeneous Markov process changes in the set ùïä={1,2}, and the TP is assumed in a polytope defined by its vertices
Furthermore, assume the uncertainty œÉ(Œ∏k) is ‚àí0.4216 when Œ∏k=1 and 0.1408 when Œ∏k=2. Hence, we have
In addition, the time delays are assumed as 1‚â§d1=1<d2=2‚â§2.
Given Œ≥=0.2, solving the optimization problem (45), we can obtain the optimal value for H‚àí index, that is, the sensitivity performance is Œ≤=1.3131 with the filter gains
In addition, assume œÇl(k),l=1,2,3, respectively, are chosen as
Thus, a set of stochastic sequence Œ∏k can be produced, as shown in Figure 1, according to

caption.p: Mode Œ∏k at the kth sampling period.

sec.p: In the following, the system is simulated under the above mode switching, and with zero initial condition, the disturbance input is w(k)=[w1T(k)w2T(k)]T, where
and w2(k), as shown in Figure 2, is random noise, and the fault occurs when 30s<k<60s.

Figures 3 and 4 show the corresponding generated residual r(k) and the evaluation function Jr(œÑ) for the faults with f(k)=1 and f(k)=2. It can be seen that the fault can be detected quickly after its occurrence by the approach proposed in this article, and the larger the fault magnitude, the more sensitive the residual becomes.

caption.p: (a) Residual |r(k)| and (b) residual evaluation function Jr(œÑ) when f(k)=1.
(a) Residual |r(k)| and (b) residual evaluation function Jr(œÑ) when f(k)=2.

sec.p: On the other hand, in order to show the advantage of the proposed method, we compare our method with the widely utilized H‚àû-filtering formulation techniques.

The corresponding generated residual r(k) and the evaluation function Jr(œÑ) by these two approaches are shown in Figures 5 and 6 when f(k)=1 and f(k)=0.09, respectively. It can be concluded from Figure 5 that the fault can be detected soon after its occurrence by both the methods when f(k)=1; however, the influence of fault on the residual of our method is larger than that of the H‚àû-filtering formulation ones. Furthermore, from Figure 6, we can see that the approach proposed in this article is effective when the magnitude of the fault is small, that is, f(k)=0.09, while the existing method cannot work well.

caption.p: (a) Residual |r(k)| and (b) residual evaluation function Jr(œÑ) when f(k)=1.
(a) Residual |r(k)| and (b) residual evaluation function Jr(œÑ) when f(k)=0.09.

sec.p: In a word, the FD approach proposed in this article with consideration of the sensitivity is more effective than the H‚àû-filtering formulation approaches.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the FD problem for a class of nonhomogeneous MJSs with mode-dependent delays and nonlinearities has been studied based on delta operator approach. After introducing the definition of stochastic H‚àí index, the FD scheme has been proposed, in which both the disturbance attenuation performance and the fault sensitivity performance have been considered. Then, new sufficient conditions to treat the proposed FD problem have been obtained in terms of LMIs, and these conditions include some existing results. An application of the linearized aircraft has shown the effectiveness of the proposed results.

sec.title: Notation
